questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent cough and fever for the past month. He has a history of working in construction and has been exposed to soil and bird droppings. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and microbial elements are observed under the microscope. His urine antigen test for the causative agent is positive and a histopathological image is shown as below. Which of the following structures is most likely observed?

options.B: Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chitin and glucan in the cell wall Explanation: This is a case of Histoplasma capsulatum infection which is a fungus and fungi have cell walls composed of chitin and glucans. The patient has a history of working in construction and being exposed to soil and bird droppings. His symptoms, including a persistent cough and fever, align with pulmonary histoplasmosis. Histoplasma can be detected by urine antigen test. Histopathological examination shows a Giemsa-stained tissue smear with macrophages containing phagocytosed yeast forms of the fungus. Giemsa-stained tissue smear shows a macrophage with phagocytosed H. capsulatum yeast forms. Property Fungi Bacteria Cell Structure Eukaryote Prokaryote Cell Wall Composition Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid (Options A, C, and D) Cytoplasmic

questions.question: A 34-year-old female presents with a persistent cough and fever after returning from a trip. A laboratory workup reveals a fungal infection. The fungus is dimorphic in nature. Which of the following cannot be the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Aspergillus fumigatus Explanation: Aspergillus species do not exhibit dimorphism. They exist only as moulds in their environmental form and do not switch to a yeast form at body temperature as is seen in dimorphic fungi. ( Mnemonic : bod Y temperature - Y east) Fungal classification based on morphology: Classification Characteristics Examples Yeast Presence of buds/budding form Cryptococcus Saccharomyces cerevisiae Yeast-like (Pseudohyphae) Elongated buds, known as pseudohyphae Candida Malassezia Trichosporon Hortae Mold/Hyphae Aseptate (non-segmented): Hyphae is Broad ribbon like without segments Zygomycetes (e.g., Mucor) Septate (segmented): Phaeoid - Masson Fontanna silver stain+ (melanin-pigmented) Hyaline hyphae Phaeoid (Piedra, Alternaria, Madurella, Curvularia) Hyaline (Fusarium, Acremonium, Aspergillus , Penicillium, Dermatophytes) Dimorphic Fungi Two morphologies: Mold at 25°C Yeast at 37°C Blastomyces Histoplasma Penicillium marneffei (Talaromyces) Coccidioides Sporothrix (Option A, B, and C)

questions.question: You are presented with an image of fungal spores. Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image given?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Formed by budding Explanation: The given image is of a sporangiospore. Sporangiospores are not formed by budding; they are produced within a sac (sporangium) by molds like Rhizopus and Mucor. Classification Sexual Spore Description Examples Zygomycetes Zygospores Non-septate hyphae. Asexual spores are called sporangiospores. Mucor (with aerial sporangiospores) Rhizopus (Rhizoid with sporangiospores above) Ascomycetes Ascospores Ascospores are formed in a sac called ascus. Penicillium Aspergillus Piedra hortae Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Basidiospores are formed externally on the tip of a pedestal called a basidium. Filobasidiella Trichosporon species Deuteromycetes (Fungi Imperfecti) None Fungi that lack a known sexual state. Coccidioides Asexual Spore Description Example Arthrospores Arise by fragmentation of the ends of hyphae Coccidioides immitis Chlamydospores Rounded, thick-walled spores Candida albicans Sporangiospores Formed within a sac (sporangium) on a stalk by molds Rhizopus, Mucor Conidiospores Arise directly from a conidiophore Aspergillus Blastospores Formed by the budding process Candida albicans

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic ulcer on her leg that has been slowly expanding over several months. She has a history of gardening and often works with soil. The physician suspects a subcutaneous mycosis. Which of the following conditions is not classified in the same group as the suspected infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tinea Versicolor Explanation: Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia and primarily affects the skin's outer layers, not classified as a subcutaneous mycosis. Classification Examples Superficial Mycosis Tinea Versicolor (Malassezia species) Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) Subcutaneous Mycosis (Option A, B, and D) Mycetoma (Madurella species) Rhinosporidiosis (Rhinosporidium seeberi) Chromoblastomycosis (Fonsecaea pedrosi, Phialophora, Cladophialophora) Sporotrichosis (Sporothrix schenckii) Deep Mycosis/Systemic Mycosis Dimorphic fungi Histoplasma Penicillium marneffei Coccidioides Sporothrix Blastomyces Opportunistic infections Candida Cryptococcus Aspergillus Mucormycosis) Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 595.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about KOH preparation for identifying fungal elements is incorrect?

options.A: Suitable for samples from skin, hair, and nails.
options.B: Percentage of KOH can be increased depending on the nature of the specimen.
options.C: Procedure involves placing the specimen in a drop of 10% KOH
options.D: KOH can be used for urine samples

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) KOH can be used for urine samples. Explanation: KOH preparation is not suitable for urine samples; it is primarily used for specimens from skin, hair, and nails, which contain keratin. Direct Examination of Fungal Specimens 1. KOH Preparation Samples: All samples except urine, CSF, blood, serum Procedure: Place the specimen in a drop of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) on a microscope slide (Option C) Cover with a coverslip and gently heat the slide. Examine under a microscope. Purpose: KOH digests keratin Direct demonstration of fungal morphology Hyphae, pseudohyphae, yeast cells Key points: Ideal for samples from skin, hair, and nails (Option A) After digestion, hyphae become visible under the microscope 10% clears tissue materials and makes the background clear The percentage of KOH can be increased according to the nature of the specimen (20%,40% such as nails, takes longer time to dissolve) (Option B) 2. KOH with Calcofluor White Procedure: Add a drop of Calcofluor White solution to the KOH preparation before placing the coverslip. Purpose: Calcofluor White binds to fungal components, causing them to fluoresce bright green when exposed to UV light. Benefits: Enhances visibility of fungal elements, making identification easier.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male patient with HIV presents with symptoms of fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is sent for analysis. Which stain is most appropriate for identifying specific organisms in this CSF sample?
questions.explanation: patients with HIV, cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection, making India Ink particularly relevant for diagnosis. Stain Description Mycology lab Calcofluor White Fluorochrome binds to glucans and chitin in the fungal cell wall, enhancing visualization of fungal elements. Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Stains chitin in the fungal cell wall Allows visualisation after scraping or tape preparation from cultures. Pathology Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) Used primarily in pathology to visualize host cell responses to fungi Does not stain most fungi, except some like Aspergillus spp. and Mucorales. Grocott Methenamine Silver (GMS) Stains fungal cell walls black, providing clear contrast for identifying fungi in tissue samples. Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) Stains the polysaccharide components of the fungal cell walls magenta Useful for detecting fungal elements in histological samples. Selected specific stains India Ink A "negative" stain outlining the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp Less sensitive than antigen detection for cryptococcal meningitis. Mucicarmine Stains the mucopolysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp.; can also stain Blastomyces and Rhinosporidium. Fontana-Masson Silver stain is used to detect melanin pigment in cell walls of Cryptococcus and pheoid moulds.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the role of mucicarmine in diagnosing Cryptococcus neoformans ? encapsulated Cryptococcus neoformans

options.A: Mucicarmine is the only stain that can identify Cryptococcus species in all clinical samples
options.B: Mucicarmine specifically stains the polysaccharide capsule, aiding in the identification of
options.C: Mucicarmine is equally effective for both encapsulated and capsule-deficient Cryptococcus strains
options.D: Mucicarmine is only useful when Cryptococcus neoformans cultures are positive

questions.explanation: identification of encapsulated Cryptococcus neoformans Correct Answer: B) Mucicarmine specifically stains the polysaccharide capsule, aiding in the identification of encapsulated Cryptococcus neoformans . Explanation: Mucicarmine is used to stain the polysaccharide capsule of C. neoformans , which is essential for identifying encapsulated forms in clinical samples. Role of Mucicarmine in Diagnosing Cryptococcus neoformans: Primary Use : Stains the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans , aiding diagnosis in immunocompromised patients. Importance : Essential for identifying encapsulated forms, especially when other diagnostic methods are insufficient. Key Diagnostic Roles of Mucicarmine: Role Description Capsule Visualization Stains the Cryptococcus capsule, which is a major virulence factor and critical for organism identification. Comparison with Other Stains Less effective with capsule-deficient strains; alternative stains like Fontana-Masson silver may be needed. Clinical Relevance Valuable when fungal cultures are negative or unavailable, especially when combined with other fungal stains. Limitations Not reliable for all Cryptococcus strains; complementary tests are necessary for accurate diagnosis. Summary: Diagnostic Aid : Useful in confirming cryptococcosis, particularly for encapsulated C. neoformans . Limitations : Capsule-deficient strains may yield negative results with mucicarmine, requiring other stains for verification. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9945492/ https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3541845/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5808417/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6399886/

questions.question: Which of the following features of Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) makes it particularly useful for culturing dermatophytes in clinical mycology?

options.A: Neutral pH and presence of antibacterial agents
options.B: Acidic pH and addition of cycloheximide
options.C: Presence of growth factors to support bacterial and fungal growth
options.D: Neutral pH and enriched with glucose for rapid bacterial growth

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acidic pH and addition of cycloheximide Explanation: SDA has an acidic pH, favouring fungal growth over bacterial growth. The addition of cycloheximide further increases specificity by inhibiting non-dermatophytic fungi, making it ideal for dermatophytes. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) in Mycology: Purpose : Used to culture fungi, especially dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum ). (Option C ruled out) pH : Acidic (pH 5.4), favouring fungal growth. (Options A&D ruled out) Additives : Chloramphenicol : Prevents bacterial contamination. Cycloheximide : Inhibits growth of non-dermatophytic fungi, enhancing specificity. Temperature for Culturing : Incubation at room temperature (22°C) and 37°C to observe growth characteristics. Fungal Identification on SDA: Identification Method Description Macroscopic Features Observed for colony colour, texture, growth rate, and appearance on both sides of the culture plate Cryptococcus: Off-white mucoid colony Candida: Creamy white pasty colony Histoplasma: White cotton growth Microscopic Examination Techniques include teased mounts, cellophane tape mounts, and slide cultures; lactophenol cotton blue stain is used. Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 596, 597, 600, 601, 602.

questions.question: A sample from a patient with suspected cryptococcosis is cultured on birdseed agar. What is the main purpose of using birdseed agar in this case?

options.A: To inhibit bacterial growth and favour fungal growth
options.B: To selectively isolate Candida species from other fungi
options.C: To promote the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans through melanin production
options.D: To enhance the growth rate of all fungal species by providing additional nutrients

questions.explanation: production Correct Answer: C) To promote the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans through melanin production Explanation: Bird seed agar is used to identify Cryptococcus neoformans , as this species produces melanin on the medium, resulting in a characteristic dark brown or black colour. Other Cultures in Mycology: Czapek-Dox Medium : Used for isolating and cultivating a wide range of fungi, particularly nutrient-demanding species. Chemically defined, allowing for precise study of fungal physiology and metabolism. Bird Seed Agar : Specifically designed for isolating and identifying Cryptococcus neoformans & gatti . (Options A&B ruled out) Contains Niger seeds, which facilitate melanin production in Cryptococcus neoformans , leading to brown to black pigmented colonies. (Option D ruled out) Corn Meal Agar : Stimulates sporulation and reveals morphological characteristics of fungi, especially yeasts like Candida albicans and Candida dubinensis . Simple medium made from corn meal extract; Tween 80 can be added to enhance chlamydospore production for identification. Note: Non-specific media, like blood agar, can be adapted for fungal use with antibacterials. Incubation Temperatures : Cultures are incubated at 22°C (room temperature) and 37°C to observe growth patterns and aid in species differentiation. Fungal Culture Techniques: Technique Purpose Macroscopic Clues Growth rate, texture, and colour help in identifying fungal species. Microscopic Analysis Reveals fungal morphology through mounts and stains, detailing hyphae, conidia. Importance of Fungal Cultures: Aspect Description Definitive Diagnosis Confirms fungal species responsible for infection, guiding specific treatments. Species Differentiation Distinguishes species by growth and microscopic traits, aiding in understanding fungi's role. Antifungal Susceptibility Testing Determines fungal sensitivity to antifungals, guiding effective therapy. Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 596, 597, 602.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation in clinical specimens?

options.A: Enhance the visibility of fungi by staining
options.B: Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures

questions.explanation: keratin, allowing fungal elements to be clearly visible under the microscope. Detection Methods for Fungi Beyond Culture Media: Method Description Use Direct Microscopic Examination KOH Preparation Dissolves keratin in clinical specimens (e.g., skin scrapings, nail clippings) to visualise fungal elements. Diagnosing dermatophyte infections Calcofluor White Staining Enhances fungal visibility by binding to chitin in cell walls, causing them to fluoresce under UV light. (Option A ruled out) Observing fungal morphology Gram Stain Traditionally for bacterial identification, also useful for yeasts, which typically stain Gram-positive (purple). Detecting certain fungi India Ink Preparation Negative staining method for encapsulated yeasts (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), revealing a clear halo around cells. Identifying encapsulated yeasts Methenamine Silver and PAS Staining Histochemical techniques that stain fungi black (methenamine) or magenta (PAS) in tissue sections. Highlighting fungi in tissues Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Mount Enhances contrast in teased fungal colonies for morphological observation. Microscopic examination of fungi Serology Antibody Detection Identifies antibodies produced by the host in response to fungi using methods like ELISA. (Option C ruled out) Tracking immune response to fungal infections Antigen Detection Detects fungal antigens in body fluids using techniques such as latex agglutination tests. Identifying fungal presence in the body Skin Tests Delayed-Type Hypersensitivity (DTH) Assesses previous exposure to fungi through localised reactions to injected antigens. Evaluating past fungal exposure Newer Rapid Diagnostic Tests Nucleic Acid Hybridisation Uses labelled DNA probes for rapid fungal DNA detection in clinical samples. Quick identification of fungal pathogens Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) Amplifies specific fungal DNA sequences, enabling early diagnosis even with low fungal loads. (Option D ruled out) Early detection of fungal infections Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 596, 597, 601.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are correct? 1. Sterols are present in the Cytoplasmic Membrane of bacteria except Mycoplasma. 2. Sterols are present in Cytoplasmic Membrane of fungi except in Pneumocystis carinii. 3. Bacteria use both asexual and sexual spores for reproduction. 4. Bacterial cell wall contains Peptidoglycan, LPS and teichoic acid. 5. Fungi have no nucleus or nuclear membrane.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 2 and 4 only Explanation: Property Fungi Bacteria Cell Structure Eukaryote Prokaryote Cell Wall Composition Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid Cytoplasmic Membrane Sterols present except in Pneumocystis carinii Sterols absent except in Mycoplasma Cytoplasmic Contents Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER) Membrane-bound organelles absent Nucleus True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome Diameter 5 – 10 µ m; may be > 100 µ m < 2 µ m Morphology Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous Cocci, bacilli, some branching Spores Both asexual and sexual for reproduction Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 593.
